title: ZenControl
trigger: A broken screen made my phone unusable.
tagline: When my phone’s display broke, I didn’t replace the phone — I replaced the way I interacted with it.
reason: Control your phone hands-free—with commands, not touch.

sections.title: Trigger
sections.content: My phone slipped from my hand, and the display **shattered beyond use**. The device still worked — but I was **blind**. Calls kept coming in, messages kept piling up, and I couldn’t respond. Buying a new phone wasn’t an option, so I was stuck with a fully functioning device that I could do nothing with.

sections.title: Pain
sections.content: Every day was the same routine: people trying to reach me, and me failing to reach back. I wasn’t without a phone — **I was trapped behind a broken screen**. It felt absurd that a slab of working hardware was useless just because I couldn’t tap the right pixels. I didn’t need sympathy. **I needed access.**

sections.title: Pull-Quote
sections.content: > I wasn’t without a phone — **I was trapped behind a broken screen**.

sections.title: Turning Point
sections.content: I realized that if **the screen was the problem**, then I didn’t need a new phone — **I needed a new interface**. I started with the bare minimum: an app that could dial pre-stored contacts and answer incoming calls. It wasn’t pretty, but it gave my phone a pulse again. That small win **changed everything.**

sections.title: What I Built
sections.content:
The first version was simple: **calls in and calls out without touching the display**. Then I expanded it — music control, toggling features, basic automation. With each update, **the screen mattered less**.

Eventually the idea shifted from controlling a *broken* phone to **controlling a phone hands-free**.

That’s when **ZenControl** was born — a personal on-device assistant that executes commands directly:

```
“Turn on the hotspot.”
“Play music.”
“Call Dad.”
```

No typing, no swiping — **just intent → action.**

sections.title: Impact
sections.content:
Instead of buying a new phone, I **repurposed a broken one into something more powerful**. ZenControl didn’t just save money — it unlocked control in situations where touchscreens normally fail:
- driving
- multitasking
- accessibility challenges
- low-vision use cases

A device that was once **unusable** became **effortless**.

sections.title: What It Taught Me
sections.content:
Limitations aren’t obstacles — **they're pressure**. Pressure forces clarity. Pressure forces innovation.

ZenControl started because I couldn’t afford a new phone. It grew because I **refused to settle for inconvenience**.

Now I approach every problem with a single question:

> **Is this truly impossible — or just inconvenient enough that people learn to live with it?**

title: NoteNest
trigger: I needed a personal space to organize my work and showcase my projects without relying on third-party platforms like Google Drive, Dropbox, or WhatsApp.
tagline: A secure, private workspace to store my notes, PDFs, and files — freeing me from reliance on external platforms.
reason: A secure, private workspace to store my notes, PDFs, and files

sections.title: Trigger
sections.content: I needed a personal space to organize my work — notes, PDFs, code snippets, and other files — without relying on external products like Google Drive, Dropbox, or WhatsApp, all of which require logins or compromise privacy.

sections.title: Pain
sections.content: Switching between multiple apps to store and showcase my work was frustrating. I needed a central, private hub where I could safely store files and display selected projects professionally.

sections.title: Turning Point
sections.content: Instead of compromising with existing platforms, I decided to build my own secure workspace. By integrating it with my portfolio website, I could manage files privately and showcase them selectively.

sections.title: What I Built
sections.content:
NoteNest is a password-protected workspace connected to my portfolio website. It allows me to:
- Store notes, PDFs, and project files securely
- Organize resources without third-party dependency
- Showcase selected files and projects to anyone I choose
- Maintain full control over personal and professional content

sections.title: Impact
sections.content: I now have a single, secure hub for both work and presentation. It’s more than storage — it’s a reflection of my process, my organization, and my ability to create tools tailored to my workflow.

sections.title: What It Taught Me
sections.content: Sometimes the best solution isn’t out there — it’s what you build yourself. NoteNest taught me autonomy, privacy, and designing tools that serve both personal and professional needs simultaneously.

title: The Chess Game
trigger: I wanted to build something undeniably complex to prove that I could take a product from idea to deployment — without waiting for industry experience.
tagline: Not a project from pain — a project from ambition.
reason: A personal challenge to build a complex, logic-heavy app that’s unforgiving to bugs — proving I could deliver a production-ready product while juggling coursework.

sections.title: Trigger
sections.content: In my 2nd year of B.Tech, I kept hearing that *real* apps only happen after internships or industry experience. I didn’t agree. I didn’t want to wait for permission — I wanted proof that I could build and deploy something complex on my own.

sections.title: Drive
sections.content: This project wasn’t fueled by pain — it was fueled by ambition. I chose chess because there are no shortcuts. The logic, state management, UI precision, and synchronisation leave no room for sloppy engineering. If I could build this, then I could build anything.

sections.title: Turning Point
sections.content: Once I committed, the scope exploded: move validation, piece logic, multiplayer states, Firebase sync, UI polish, persistence. Instead of stepping back, I doubled down. I attended classes in the day and built through the night. I wasn’t working on an assignment — I was building a product.

sections.title: What I Built
sections.content:
A full-fledged chess application featuring:
- Online multiplayer with Firebase
- Real-time move synchronization
- Clean Jetpack Compose UI
- Local mode and a bot to practice with

The app underwent a 20-user test for 15 days — not for feedback, but because it was required for Play Store deployment. I cleared it and shipped.

sections.title: Impact
sections.content: The goal wasn’t downloads or virality. The win was proving that I could take an idea from **scratch → shipped app** while managing coursework and complexity. It wasn’t luck — it was persistence, engineering, and execution.

sections.title: What It Taught Me
sections.content: Some projects are born from frustration. This one was born from belief. I learned that validation doesn’t come from praise — it comes from finishing what you start. Today, when someone says students can’t build production-grade apps, I don’t argue. I just point to the app on the Play Store.
